trans-unit.target: .NET, .NET Core

trans-unit.source: Working with LINQ
trans-unit.target: Working with LINQ

trans-unit.source: Introduction
trans-unit.target: Introduction

trans-unit.source: This tutorial teaches you a number of features in .NET Core and the C# language.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial teaches you a number of features in .NET Core and the C# language.

trans-unit.source: You’ll learn:
trans-unit.target: You’ll learn:

trans-unit.source: How to generate sequences with LINQ
trans-unit.target: How to generate sequences with LINQ

trans-unit.source: How to write methods that can be easily used in LINQ queries.
trans-unit.target: How to write methods that can be easily used in LINQ queries.

trans-unit.source: How to distinguish between eager and lazy evaluation.
trans-unit.target: How to distinguish between eager and lazy evaluation.

trans-unit.source: You'll learn these techniques by building an application that demonstrates one of the basic skills of any magician: the [faro shuffle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Faro_shuffle).
trans-unit.target: You'll learn these techniques by building an application that demonstrates one of the basic skills of any magician: the [faro shuffle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Faro_shuffle).

trans-unit.source: Briefly, a faro shuffle is a technique where you split a card deck exactly in half, then the shuffle interleaves each one card from each half to rebuild the original deck.
trans-unit.target: Briefly, a faro shuffle is a technique where you split a card deck exactly in half, then the shuffle interleaves each one card from each half to rebuild the original deck.

trans-unit.source: Magicians use this technique because every card is in a known location after each shuffle, and the order is a repeating pattern.
trans-unit.target: Magicians use this technique because every card is in a known location after each shuffle, and the order is a repeating pattern.

trans-unit.source: For our purposes, it is a light hearted look at manipulating sequences of data.
trans-unit.target: For our purposes, it is a light hearted look at manipulating sequences of data.

trans-unit.source: The application you'll build will construct a card deck, and then perform a sequence of shuffles, writing the sequence out each time.
trans-unit.target: The application you'll build will construct a card deck, and then perform a sequence of shuffles, writing the sequence out each time.

trans-unit.source: You'll also compare the updated order to the original order.
trans-unit.target: You'll also compare the updated order to the original order.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial has multiple steps.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial has multiple steps.

trans-unit.source: After each step, you can run the application and see the progress.
trans-unit.target: After each step, you can run the application and see the progress.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: You’ll need to setup your machine to run .NET core.
trans-unit.target: You’ll need to setup your machine to run .NET core.

trans-unit.source: You can find the installation instructions on the [.NET Core](https://www.microsoft.com/net/core) page.
trans-unit.target: You can find the installation instructions on the [.NET Core](https://www.microsoft.com/net/core) page.

trans-unit.source: You can run this application on Windows, Ubuntu Linux, OS X or in a Docker container.
trans-unit.target: You can run this application on Windows, Ubuntu Linux, OS X or in a Docker container.

trans-unit.source: You’ll need to install your favorite code editor.
trans-unit.target: You’ll need to install your favorite code editor.

trans-unit.source: The descriptions below use [Visual Studio Code](https://code.visualstudio.com/) which is an open source, cross platform editor.
trans-unit.target: The descriptions below use [Visual Studio Code](https://code.visualstudio.com/) which is an open source, cross platform editor.

trans-unit.source: However, you can use whatever tools you are comfortable with.
trans-unit.target: However, you can use whatever tools you are comfortable with.

trans-unit.source: Create the Application
trans-unit.target: Create the Application

trans-unit.source: The first step is to create a new application.
trans-unit.target: The first step is to create a new application.

trans-unit.source: Open a command prompt and create a new directory for your application.
trans-unit.target: Open a command prompt and create a new directory for your application.

trans-unit.source: Make that the current directory.
trans-unit.target: Make that the current directory.

trans-unit.source: Type the command "dotnet new" at the command prompt.
trans-unit.target: Type the command "dotnet new" at the command prompt.

trans-unit.source: This creates the starter files for a basic “Hello World” application.
trans-unit.target: This creates the starter files for a basic “Hello World” application.

trans-unit.source: If you've never used C# before, [this tutorial](console-teleprompter.md) explains the structure of a C# program.
trans-unit.target: If you've never used C# before, [this tutorial](console-teleprompter.md) explains the structure of a C# program.

trans-unit.source: You can read that and then return here to learn more about LINQ.
trans-unit.target: You can read that and then return here to learn more about LINQ.

trans-unit.source: Creating the Data Set
trans-unit.target: Creating the Data Set

trans-unit.source: Let's start by creating a deck of cards.
trans-unit.target: Let's start by creating a deck of cards.

trans-unit.source: You'll do this using a LINQ query that has two sources (one for the four suits, one for the thirteen values).
trans-unit.target: You'll do this using a LINQ query that has two sources (one for the four suits, one for the thirteen values).

trans-unit.source: You'll combine those source into a 52 card deck.
trans-unit.target: You'll combine those source into a 52 card deck.

trans-unit.source: Here's the query:
trans-unit.target: Here's the query:

trans-unit.source: The multiple `from` clauses produce a `SelectMany`, which creates a single sequence from combining each element in the first sequence with each element in the second sequence.
trans-unit.target: The multiple `from` clauses produce a `SelectMany`, which creates a single sequence from combining each element in the first sequence with each element in the second sequence.

trans-unit.source: The order is important for our purposes.
trans-unit.target: The order is important for our purposes.

trans-unit.source: The first element in the first source sequence (Suits) is combined with every element in the second sequence (Values).
trans-unit.target: The first element in the first source sequence (Suits) is combined with every element in the second sequence (Values).

trans-unit.source: This produces all thirteen cards of first suit.
trans-unit.target: This produces all thirteen cards of first suit.

trans-unit.source: That process is repeated with each element in the first sequence (Suits).
trans-unit.target: That process is repeated with each element in the first sequence (Suits).

trans-unit.source: The end result is a deck of cards ordered by suits, followed by values.
trans-unit.target: The end result is a deck of cards ordered by suits, followed by values.

trans-unit.source: Next, you'll need to build the Suits() and Ranks() methods.
trans-unit.target: Next, you'll need to build the Suits() and Ranks() methods.

trans-unit.source: Let's start with a really simple set of *iterator methods* that generate the sequence as an enumerable of strings:
trans-unit.target: Let's start with a really simple set of *iterator methods* that generate the sequence as an enumerable of strings:

trans-unit.source: These two methods both utilize the `yield return` syntax to produce a sequence as they run.
trans-unit.target: These two methods both utilize the `yield return` syntax to produce a sequence as they run.

trans-unit.source: The compiler builds an object that implements `IEnumerable<T>` and generates the sequence of strings as they are requested.
trans-unit.target: The compiler builds an object that implements `IEnumerable<T>` and generates the sequence of strings as they are requested.

trans-unit.source: Go ahead and run the sample you've built at this point.
trans-unit.target: Go ahead and run the sample you've built at this point.

trans-unit.source: It will display all 52 cards in the deck.
trans-unit.target: It will display all 52 cards in the deck.

trans-unit.source: You may find it very helpful to run this sample under a debugger to observe how the `Suits()` and `Values()` methods execute.
trans-unit.target: You may find it very helpful to run this sample under a debugger to observe how the `Suits()` and `Values()` methods execute.

trans-unit.source: You can clearly see that each string in each sequence is generated only as it is needed.
trans-unit.target: You can clearly see that each string in each sequence is generated only as it is needed.

trans-unit.source: Manipulating the Order
trans-unit.target: Manipulating the Order

trans-unit.source: Next, let's build a utility method that can perform the shuffle.
trans-unit.target: Next, let's build a utility method that can perform the shuffle.

trans-unit.source: The first step is to split the deck in two.
trans-unit.target: The first step is to split the deck in two.

trans-unit.source: The `Take()` and `Skip()` methods that are part of the LINQ APIs provide that feature for us:
trans-unit.target: The `Take()` and `Skip()` methods that are part of the LINQ APIs provide that feature for us:

trans-unit.source: The shuffle method doesn't exist in the standard library, so you'll have to write your own.
trans-unit.target: The shuffle method doesn't exist in the standard library, so you'll have to write your own.

trans-unit.source: This new method illustrates several techniques that you'll use with LINQ-based programs, so let's explain each part of the method in steps.
trans-unit.target: This new method illustrates several techniques that you'll use with LINQ-based programs, so let's explain each part of the method in steps.

trans-unit.source: The signature for the method creates an *extension method*:
trans-unit.target: The signature for the method creates an *extension method*:

trans-unit.source: An extension method is a special purpose *static method.*
trans-unit.target: An extension method is a special purpose *static method.*

trans-unit.source: You can see the addition of the `this` modifier on the first argument to the method.
trans-unit.target: You can see the addition of the `this` modifier on the first argument to the method.

trans-unit.source: That means you call the method as though it were a member method of the type of the first argument.
trans-unit.target: That means you call the method as though it were a member method of the type of the first argument.

trans-unit.source: Extension methods can be declared only inside `static` classes, so let's create a new static class called `extensions` for this functionality.
trans-unit.target: Extension methods can be declared only inside `static` classes, so let's create a new static class called `extensions` for this functionality.

trans-unit.source: You'll add more extension methods as you continue this tutorial, and those will be placed in the same class.
trans-unit.target: You'll add more extension methods as you continue this tutorial, and those will be placed in the same class.

trans-unit.source: This method declaration also follows a standard idiom where the input and output types are `IEnumerable<T>`.
trans-unit.target: This method declaration also follows a standard idiom where the input and output types are `IEnumerable<T>`.

trans-unit.source: That practice enables LINQ methods to be chained together to perform more complex queries.
trans-unit.target: That practice enables LINQ methods to be chained together to perform more complex queries.

trans-unit.source: You will be enumerating both sequences at once, interleaving the elements, and creating one object.
trans-unit.target: You will be enumerating both sequences at once, interleaving the elements, and creating one object.

trans-unit.source: Writing a LINQ method that works with two sequences requires that you understand how `IEnumerable` works.
trans-unit.target: Writing a LINQ method that works with two sequences requires that you understand how `IEnumerable` works.

trans-unit.source: The `IEnumerable` interface has one method: `GetEnumerator()`.
trans-unit.target: The `IEnumerable` interface has one method: `GetEnumerator()`.

trans-unit.source: The object returned by `GetEnumerator()` has a method to move to the next element, and a property that retrieves the current element in the sequence.
trans-unit.target: The object returned by `GetEnumerator()` has a method to move to the next element, and a property that retrieves the current element in the sequence.

trans-unit.source: You will use those two members to enumerate the collection and return the elements.
trans-unit.target: You will use those two members to enumerate the collection and return the elements.

trans-unit.source: This Interleave method will be an iterator method, so instead of building a collection and returning the collection, you'll use the `yield return` syntax shown above.
trans-unit.target: This Interleave method will be an iterator method, so instead of building a collection and returning the collection, you'll use the `yield return` syntax shown above.

trans-unit.target: Here's the implementation of that method:

trans-unit.target: Now that you've written this method, go back to the `Main` method and shuffle the deck once:

trans-unit.source: Comparisons
trans-unit.target: Comparisons

trans-unit.source: Let's see how many shuffles it takes to set the deck back to its original order.
trans-unit.target: Let's see how many shuffles it takes to set the deck back to its original order.

trans-unit.source: You'll need to write a method that determines if two sequences are equal.
trans-unit.target: You'll need to write a method that determines if two sequences are equal.

trans-unit.source: After you have that method, you'll need to place the code that shuffles the deck in a loop, and check to see when the deck is back in order.
trans-unit.target: After you have that method, you'll need to place the code that shuffles the deck in a loop, and check to see when the deck is back in order.

trans-unit.source: Writing a method to determine if the two sequences are equal should be straightforward.
trans-unit.target: Writing a method to determine if the two sequences are equal should be straightforward.

trans-unit.source: It's a similar structure to the method you wrote to shuffle the deck.
trans-unit.target: It's a similar structure to the method you wrote to shuffle the deck.

trans-unit.source: Only this time, instead of yield returning each element, you'll compare the matching elements of each sequence.
trans-unit.target: Only this time, instead of yield returning each element, you'll compare the matching elements of each sequence.

trans-unit.source: When the entire sequence has been enumerated, if every element matches, the sequences are the same:
trans-unit.target: When the entire sequence has been enumerated, if every element matches, the sequences are the same:

trans-unit.source: This shows a second Linq idiom: terminal methods.
trans-unit.target: This shows a second Linq idiom: terminal methods.

trans-unit.source: They take a sequence as input (or in this case, two sequences), and return a single scalar value.
trans-unit.target: They take a sequence as input (or in this case, two sequences), and return a single scalar value.

trans-unit.source: These methods, when they are used, are always the final method of a query.
trans-unit.target: These methods, when they are used, are always the final method of a query.

trans-unit.source: (Hence the name).
trans-unit.target: (Hence the name).

trans-unit.source: You can see this in action when you use it to determine when the deck is back in its original order.
trans-unit.target: You can see this in action when you use it to determine when the deck is back in its original order.

trans-unit.source: Put the shuffle code inside a loop, and stop when the sequence is back in its original order by applying the `SequenceEquals()` method.
trans-unit.target: Put the shuffle code inside a loop, and stop when the sequence is back in its original order by applying the `SequenceEquals()` method.

trans-unit.source: You can see it would always be the final method in any query, because it returns a single value instead of a sequence:
trans-unit.target: You can see it would always be the final method in any query, because it returns a single value instead of a sequence:

trans-unit.source: Run the sample, and see how the deck rearranges on each shuffle, until it returns to its original configuration after 8 iterations.
trans-unit.target: Run the sample, and see how the deck rearranges on each shuffle, until it returns to its original configuration after 8 iterations.

trans-unit.source: Optimizations
trans-unit.target: Optimizations

trans-unit.source: The sample you've built so far executes an *in shuffle*, where the top and bottom cards stay the same on each run.
trans-unit.target: The sample you've built so far executes an *in shuffle*, where the top and bottom cards stay the same on each run.

trans-unit.source: Let's make one change, and run an *out shuffle*, where all 52 cards change position.
trans-unit.target: Let's make one change, and run an *out shuffle*, where all 52 cards change position.

trans-unit.source: For an out shuffle, you interleave the deck so that the first card in the bottom half becomes the first card in the deck.
trans-unit.target: For an out shuffle, you interleave the deck so that the first card in the bottom half becomes the first card in the deck.

trans-unit.source: That means the last card in the top half becomes the bottom card.
trans-unit.target: That means the last card in the top half becomes the bottom card.

trans-unit.source: That's just a one line change.
trans-unit.target: That's just a one line change.

trans-unit.source: Update the call to shuffle to change the order of the top and bottom halves of the deck:
trans-unit.target: Update the call to shuffle to change the order of the top and bottom halves of the deck:

trans-unit.source: Run the program again, and you'll see that it takes 52 iterations for the deck to reorder itself.
trans-unit.target: Run the program again, and you'll see that it takes 52 iterations for the deck to reorder itself.

trans-unit.source: You'll also start to notice some serious performance degradations as the program continues to run.
trans-unit.target: You'll also start to notice some serious performance degradations as the program continues to run.

trans-unit.source: There are a number of reasons for this.
trans-unit.target: There are a number of reasons for this.

trans-unit.source: Let's tackle one of the major causes: inefficient use of *lazy evaluation*.
trans-unit.target: Let's tackle one of the major causes: inefficient use of *lazy evaluation*.

trans-unit.source: LINQ queries are evaluated lazily.
trans-unit.target: LINQ queries are evaluated lazily.

trans-unit.source: The sequences are generated only as the elements are requested.
trans-unit.target: The sequences are generated only as the elements are requested.

trans-unit.source: Usually, that's a major benefit of LINQ.
trans-unit.target: Usually, that's a major benefit of LINQ.

trans-unit.source: However, in a use such as this program, this causes exponential growth in execution time.
trans-unit.target: However, in a use such as this program, this causes exponential growth in execution time.

trans-unit.source: The original deck was generated using a LINQ query.
trans-unit.target: The original deck was generated using a LINQ query.

trans-unit.source: Each shuffle is generated by performing three LINQ queries on the previous deck.
trans-unit.target: Each shuffle is generated by performing three LINQ queries on the previous deck.

trans-unit.source: All these are performed lazily.
trans-unit.target: All these are performed lazily.

trans-unit.source: That also means they are performed again each time the sequence is requested.
trans-unit.target: That also means they are performed again each time the sequence is requested.

trans-unit.source: By the time you get to the 52nd iteration, you're regenerating the original deck many, many times.
trans-unit.target: By the time you get to the 52nd iteration, you're regenerating the original deck many, many times.

trans-unit.source: Let's write a log to demonstrate this behavior.
trans-unit.target: Let's write a log to demonstrate this behavior.

trans-unit.source: Then, you'll fix it.
trans-unit.target: Then, you'll fix it.

trans-unit.source: Here's a log method that can be appended to any query to mark that the query executed.
trans-unit.target: Here's a log method that can be appended to any query to mark that the query executed.

trans-unit.source: Next, instrument the definition of each query with a log message:
trans-unit.target: Next, instrument the definition of each query with a log message:

trans-unit.source: Notice that you don't log every time you access a query.
trans-unit.target: Notice that you don't log every time you access a query.

trans-unit.source: You log only when you create the original query.
trans-unit.target: You log only when you create the original query.

trans-unit.source: The program still takes a long time to run, but now you can see why.
trans-unit.target: The program still takes a long time to run, but now you can see why.

trans-unit.source: If you run out of patience running the outer shuffle with logging turned on, switch back to the inner shuffle.
trans-unit.target: If you run out of patience running the outer shuffle with logging turned on, switch back to the inner shuffle.

trans-unit.source: You'll still see the lazy evaluation effects.
trans-unit.target: You'll still see the lazy evaluation effects.

trans-unit.source: In one run, it executes 2592 queries, including all the value and suit generation.
trans-unit.target: In one run, it executes 2592 queries, including all the value and suit generation.

trans-unit.source: There is an easy way to update this program to avoid all those executions.
trans-unit.target: There is an easy way to update this program to avoid all those executions.

trans-unit.source: There are LINQ methods `ToArray()` and `ToList()` that cause the query to run, and store the results in an array or a list, respectively.
trans-unit.target: There are LINQ methods `ToArray()` and `ToList()` that cause the query to run, and store the results in an array or a list, respectively.

trans-unit.source: You use these methods to cache the data results of a query rather than execute the source query again.
trans-unit.target: You use these methods to cache the data results of a query rather than execute the source query again.

trans-unit.source: Append the queries that generate the card decks with a call to `ToArray()` and run the query again:
trans-unit.target: Append the queries that generate the card decks with a call to `ToArray()` and run the query again:

trans-unit.source: Run again, and the inner shuffle is down to 30 queries.
trans-unit.target: Run again, and the inner shuffle is down to 30 queries.

trans-unit.source: Run again with the outer shuffle and you'll see similar improvements.
trans-unit.target: Run again with the outer shuffle and you'll see similar improvements.

trans-unit.source: (It now executes 162 queries).
trans-unit.target: (It now executes 162 queries).

trans-unit.source: Don't misinterpret this example by thinking that all queries should run eagerly.
trans-unit.target: Don't misinterpret this example by thinking that all queries should run eagerly.

trans-unit.source: This example is designed to highlight the use cases where lazy evaluation can cause performance difficulties.
trans-unit.target: This example is designed to highlight the use cases where lazy evaluation can cause performance difficulties.

trans-unit.source: That's because each new arrangement of the deck of cards is built from the previous arrangement.
trans-unit.target: That's because each new arrangement of the deck of cards is built from the previous arrangement.

trans-unit.source: Using lazy evaluation means each new deck configuration is built from the original deck, even executing the code that built the `startingDeck`.
trans-unit.target: Using lazy evaluation means each new deck configuration is built from the original deck, even executing the code that built the `startingDeck`.

trans-unit.source: That causes a large amount of extra work.
trans-unit.target: That causes a large amount of extra work.

trans-unit.source: In practice, some algorithms run much better using eager evaluation, and others run much better using lazy evaluation.
trans-unit.target: In practice, some algorithms run much better using eager evaluation, and others run much better using lazy evaluation.

trans-unit.source: (In general, lazy evaluation is a much better choice when the data source is a separate process, like a database engine.
trans-unit.target: (In general, lazy evaluation is a much better choice when the data source is a separate process, like a database engine.

trans-unit.source: In those cases, lazy evaluation enables more complex queries to execute only one round trip to the database process.) LINQ enables both lazy and eager evaluation.
trans-unit.target: In those cases, lazy evaluation enables more complex queries to execute only one round trip to the database process.) LINQ enables both lazy and eager evaluation.

trans-unit.source: Measure, and pick the best choice.
trans-unit.target: Measure, and pick the best choice.

trans-unit.source: Preparing for New Features
trans-unit.target: Preparing for New Features

trans-unit.source: The code you've written for this sample is an example of creating a simple prototype that does the job.
trans-unit.target: The code you've written for this sample is an example of creating a simple prototype that does the job.

trans-unit.source: This is a great way to explore a problem space, and for many features, it may be the best permanent solution.
trans-unit.target: This is a great way to explore a problem space, and for many features, it may be the best permanent solution.

trans-unit.source: You've leveraged *anonymous types* for the cards, and each card is represented by strings.
trans-unit.target: You've leveraged *anonymous types* for the cards, and each card is represented by strings.

trans-unit.source: *Anonymous Types* have many productivity advantages.
trans-unit.target: *Anonymous Types* have many productivity advantages.

trans-unit.source: You don't need to define a class yourself to represent the storage.
trans-unit.target: You don't need to define a class yourself to represent the storage.

trans-unit.source: The compiler generates the type for you.
trans-unit.target: The compiler generates the type for you.

trans-unit.source: The compiler generated type utilizes many of the best practices for simple data objects.
trans-unit.target: The compiler generated type utilizes many of the best practices for simple data objects.

trans-unit.source: It's *immutable*, meaning that none of its properties can be changed after it has been constructed.
trans-unit.target: It's *immutable*, meaning that none of its properties can be changed after it has been constructed.

trans-unit.source: Anonymous types are internal to an assembly, so they aren't seen as part of the public API for that assembly.
trans-unit.target: Anonymous types are internal to an assembly, so they aren't seen as part of the public API for that assembly.

trans-unit.source: Anonymous types also contain an override of the `ToString()` method that returns a formatted string with each of the values.
trans-unit.target: Anonymous types also contain an override of the `ToString()` method that returns a formatted string with each of the values.

trans-unit.source: Anonymous types also have disadvantages.
trans-unit.target: Anonymous types also have disadvantages.

trans-unit.source: They don't have accessible names, so you can't use them as return values or arguments.
trans-unit.target: They don't have accessible names, so you can't use them as return values or arguments.

trans-unit.source: You'll notice that any methods above that used these anonymous types are generic methods.
trans-unit.target: You'll notice that any methods above that used these anonymous types are generic methods.

trans-unit.source: The override of `ToString()` may not be what you want as the application grows more features.
trans-unit.target: The override of `ToString()` may not be what you want as the application grows more features.

trans-unit.source: The sample also uses strings for the suit and the rank of each card.
trans-unit.target: The sample also uses strings for the suit and the rank of each card.

trans-unit.source: That's quite open ended.
trans-unit.target: That's quite open ended.

trans-unit.source: The C# type system can help us make better code, by leveraging `enum` types for those values.
trans-unit.target: The C# type system can help us make better code, by leveraging `enum` types for those values.

trans-unit.source: Start with the suits.
trans-unit.target: Start with the suits.

trans-unit.source: As one final cleanup, let's make a type to represent the card, instead of relying on an anonymous type.
trans-unit.target: As one final cleanup, let's make a type to represent the card, instead of relying on an anonymous type.

trans-unit.source: Anonymous types are great for lightweight, local types, but in this example, the playing card is one of the main concepts.
trans-unit.target: Anonymous types are great for lightweight, local types, but in this example, the playing card is one of the main concepts.

trans-unit.source: It should be a concrete type.
trans-unit.target: It should be a concrete type.

trans-unit.source: This type uses *auto-implemented read-only properties* which are set in the constructor, and then cannot be modified.
trans-unit.target: This type uses *auto-implemented read-only properties* which are set in the constructor, and then cannot be modified.

trans-unit.source: It also makes use of the new *string interpolation* feature that makes it easier to format string output.
trans-unit.target: It also makes use of the new *string interpolation* feature that makes it easier to format string output.

trans-unit.source: Conclusion
trans-unit.target: Conclusion

trans-unit.source: This sample should you some of the methods used in LINQ, how to create your own methods that will be easily used with LINQ enabled code.
trans-unit.target: This sample should you some of the methods used in LINQ, how to create your own methods that will be easily used with LINQ enabled code.

trans-unit.source: It also showed you the differences between lazy and eager evaluation, and the affect that decision can have on performance.
trans-unit.target: It also showed you the differences between lazy and eager evaluation, and the affect that decision can have on performance.

trans-unit.source: And, you learned a bit about one magician's technique.
trans-unit.target: And, you learned a bit about one magician's technique.

trans-unit.source: Magician's use the faro shuffle because they can control where every card moves in the deck.
trans-unit.target: Magician's use the faro shuffle because they can control where every card moves in the deck.

trans-unit.source: In some tricks, the magician has an audience member place a card on top of the deck, and shuffles a few times, knowing where that card goes.
trans-unit.target: In some tricks, the magician has an audience member place a card on top of the deck, and shuffles a few times, knowing where that card goes.

trans-unit.source: Other illusions require the deck set a certain way.
trans-unit.target: Other illusions require the deck set a certain way.

trans-unit.source: A magician will set the deck prior to performing the trick.
trans-unit.target: A magician will set the deck prior to performing the trick.

trans-unit.source: Then she will shuffle the deck 5 times using an inner shuffle.
trans-unit.target: Then she will shuffle the deck 5 times using an inner shuffle.

trans-unit.source: On stage, she can show what looks like a random deck, shuffle it 3 more times, and have the deck set exactly how she wants.
trans-unit.target: On stage, she can show what looks like a random deck, shuffle it 3 more times, and have the deck set exactly how she wants.
